message_1:
Given the following scenario:

John and Mary are both invited to a party, but they arrive separately. John knows that if Mary arrives, she will bring chocolate cake. Mary knows that if John arrives, he will bring chips. Assume that John does not know whether Mary has arrived, and Mary does not know whether John has arrived. 

What can we infer about whether the chocolate cake and chips are both at the party or not, using the principles and rules of Epistemic Logic?
message_2:
In Epistemic Logic, we use the knowledge operator K to represent what an agent knows. Let's use the following notation:

J: John arrives at the party
M: Mary arrives at the party
C: Chocolate cake is at the party
P: Chips are at the party

We are given the following information:

1. K_J(M -> C): John knows that if Mary arrives, she will bring chocolate cake.
2. K_M(J -> P): Mary knows that if John arrives, he will bring chips.
3. ¬K_J(M): John does not know whether Mary has arrived.
4. ¬K_M(J): Mary does not know whether John has arrived.

We want to infer whether both chocolate cake and chips are at the party, i.e., whether (C ∧ P) is true.

First, let's analyze the implications given in (1) and (2):

1. M -> C: If Mary arrives, there will be chocolate cake.
2. J -> P: If John arrives, there will be chips.

Now, let's consider the possible scenarios:

Scenario 1: Both John and Mary arrive (J ∧ M)
In this case, there will be chocolate cake (C) because of (1) and chips (P) because of (2). So, (C ∧ P) is true.

Scenario 2: Only John arrives (J ∧ ¬M)
In this case, there will be chips (P) because of (2), but there won't be chocolate cake (¬C) since Mary didn't arrive. So, (C ∧ P) is false.

Scenario 3: Only Mary arrives (¬J ∧ M)
In this case, there will be chocolate cake (C) because of (1), but there won't be chips (¬P) since John didn't arrive. So, (C ∧ P) is false.

Scenario 4: Neither John nor Mary arrive (¬J ∧ ¬M)
In this case, there won't be chocolate cake (¬C) or chips (¬P) since neither John nor Mary arrived. So, (C ∧ P) is false.

From the analysis of the possible scenarios, we can infer that the only situation in which both chocolate cake and chips are at the party is when both John and Mary arrive (Scenario 1). However, since John and Mary do not know whether the other has arrived (given by (3) and (4)), we cannot conclude with certainty whether both chocolate cake and chips are at the party or not.
